metadata.title: The AI That Learned To Talk Like a Politician | by Thomas Smith | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: The AI That Learned To Talk Like a Politician

all_paragraphs: In a previous article, I shared some details about Cloudsight’s AI platform, which is able to describe images in full, human-readable sentences.

The Cloudsight team has been kind enough to share a ton of details about how their system works, and I’ll be delving into these in depth. I think their platform is an interesting Deep Learning case study, and reveals insights that are relevant to anyone working in Artificial Intelligence and data science.

When Cloudsight was creating their neural network driven captioning platform, they ran into a training challenge that I think is fascinating. It’s like overfitting, but with a twist. And it inadvertently led to an AI which trained itself to speak like a politician!

With Cloudsight’s platform, users upload an image, and the system tries to describe it with a full sentence caption. The basic architecture of their system uses Neural Networks in a transformer-based approach to create their captions, drawing on a giant training set of mostly ecommerce images.

In training their model, they followed the standard protocol for training a NN. You feed it input, evaluate its output, and let it propagate errors back through its nodes, changing the weights of different inputs and hidden layers. Then you do the whole thing again, over and over, for a certain number of training epochs.

With NNs, there are really no stopping conditions. So the usual protocol is to monitor the output, and see when the error rate plateaus. When that happens, you can be fairly certain the model has found a minima on the error surface.

Perhaps you run the model again with different starting conditions, making sure you found a global minima and not a local minima. But at the end, you see a clear plateau, and know the model is fully trained and you can stop.

Cloudsight’s protocol is a bit different, because their evaluation criteria are a bit different. The captions their system generates have to make sense to a person. So to choose the proper number of training epochs, they have to run their system’s output by a person, who decides if the NN’s captions accurately describe an image.
But here’s the catch. There’s a loophole in this system.

At first, Cloudsight found that their untrained NN did a good job of generating very specific captions. For the training image at the top of this article, for example, it wrote “man in white crew neck t shirt and green shorts holding tennis racket”, “man holding tennis racket on green field”, etc.
That’s very specific — you get a description of the gender of the person, the action they’re performing (generally), and their clothing.

It’s also wrong. The man is wearing white shorts, not green ones. The model likely saw the green color from the other person bending down, and assigned the “green shorts” to the man holding the racket. And he’s on a court, not a field.

Under Cloudsight’s evaluation criteria, the NN got penalized for producing this incorrect output. So it did something very interesting. With each successive training epoch, it got more general. So instead of even attempting to describe the person’s clothing, the setting, etc it slowly veered towards descriptions like “a person standing” or just “a person.”
Here’s the thing — that output is technically correct. The image does depict a person. So the NN would score a “correct” on that output, even if the output is very, very general.
To paraphrase R.E.M., the system had learned “a way to talk around the problem.”

In effect, as Cloudsight pointed out in their internal reviews, the NN had figured out how to act like a politician — choosing output that has very little actual content, and thus always avoids saying anything wrong.
Interviewer: Sir, where do you stand on tax breaks?
Politician: I feel that all American people have the right to live up to their full potential, in this great land that we call home.
The issue, of course, is that while the general output is technically correct according to Cloudsight’s evaluation criteria, it’s also kind of useless as an actual caption.
Sure, the image does contain a person. But it’s the actions they’re performing, what they’re holding, etc. that actually matter.
Cloudsight’s challenge here was essentially one of overfitting — but with a new wrinkle.

Anyone in data science is familiar with the problem of overfitting to training data. Choose data that’s too domain-specific or too narrow, and you can train a regression model or NN that does very well on it. But unleash that model on the real world, and it will do terribly. You’ve “overfit” your model to the training data, and it’s not able to process anything outside your training set.
Cloudsight’s system faced a different version of overfitting. Rather than overfitting to the training data, it had overfit to the evaluation criteria.

Instead of actually getting better at describing images, it had gotten really good at producing outfit that gamed the system, satisfying the evaluation criteria (“Does this caption accurately describe the visual content of the image?”) while missing the actual business/technical use case for the system (providing a human-readable image caption).

This illustrates the importance of choosing your evaluation criteria very carefully when training a NN or other Deep Learning model. Modern NNs are powerful. They will learn to satisfy your evaluation criteria. But if the criteria are flawed, so will be your output.
Cloudsight solved this issue by tailoring the number of training epochs — and thus the accuracy/generality of the model — to specific customers’ use cases.

For some users, a more verbose — but possibly inaccurate — caption would be fine. Perhaps they have their own humans in the loop, who could catch errors like the green shorts and make a simple change to the computer-generated caption. For these users (like those in the stock photo industry), Cloudsight can train through fewer epochs (an average of 4), skewing the results more towards verbosity and specificity, with a possible loss of accuracy.

For other users, accuracy is crucial — they’d rather have a general caption than an inaccurate one. For them, “a person” might be fine, and would be better than a more specific caption that’s more likely to be inaccurate. Basically, they want a politician. This makes sense for users with limited resources for manually checking captions, or users processing tons of images (like for an ecommerce platform). For these users, Cloudsight trains through an average of 18 epochs, making for much more general, but usually more accurate, output.

Basically, Cloudsight is recognizing that their training protocol has to strike a balance between accuracy and generality, and is setting the threshold and cutoff between the two at different points for different users, by training through a varying number of epochs (between 3 and 20 on average).

Again, Cloudsight’s experiences underscore the importance of setting your evaluation criteria appropriately when training a Deep Learning system. Just because you’re getting error-free output doesn’t mean you’ve actually solved the real-world problem you set out to address.

It also illustrates the importance of involving a human team in your evaluation process. Humans can spot examples of overfitting, and devise solutions tailored to a specific business case. For Cloudsight, this meant using their overfitting problem as a tool, tailoring the number of training epochs to different customer use cases and thus varying their model’s output.

For others, it might mean knowing when to ask for more data, to avoid overfitting to a specific dataset. Or it might mean looking for training data beyond public datasets, to ensure that you’re not overfitting to materials which are already available to your competition.
It’s also probably a commentary on politicians — but that’s a topic for another article!
